print the first NUM lines instead of the first 10; with the leading '-', print all
 but the last NUM lines of each file

Top-3 Scripts:
ul_226082: $ OPTS="\"-name user -age 20 -where Asia -eats Brains\""
$ grep -Po -- '-where \K\w*' <<< "$OPTS"
Asia

$ grep -Po -- '-eats \K[_\"[:alnum:]]*' <<< $OPTS
Brains"

so_35287738: grep --help

$ echo 'hello world' | grep -o hello
hello

so_61217327: paste <( grep -o "[0-9][0-9]*/[0-9][0-9]*/[0-9][0-9]*" list.txt  ) list.txt | sort -n -t/ -k3,3 -k1,1 -k2,2 | cut -f2-

grep -o

$ grep -o "[0-9][0-9]*/[0-9][0-9]*/[0-9][0-9]*" list.txt
4/20/2020
4/10/2020
5/25/2020
4/15/2020

paste <( grep -o "[0-9][0-9]*/[0-9][0-9]*/[0-9][0-9]*" list.txt) list.txt

$ paste <( grep -o "[0-9][0-9]*/[0-9][0-9]*/[0-9][0-9]*" list.txt) list.txt

4/10/2020   Finish reading "the one thing" 4/10/2020
5/25/2020   verify video has been posted 5/25/2020
4/15/2020   4/15/2020 call bob

$ grep -o "[0-9][0-9]*/[0-9][0-9]*/[0-9][0-9]*" list.txt | paste -  list.txt

Explanations about Options.-o:
Print only the matched (non-empty) parts of a matching line, with each such part on
 a separate output line.
Explanations about Options.-P:
Interpret PATTERNS as Perl-compatible regular expressions (PCREs). This option is
 experimental when combined with the -z (--null-data) option, and grep -P may warn
 of unimplemented features.

Top-3 Scripts:
so_27149772: $ echo "MAC evbyminsd58df" | sed 's/ .*//'
MAC

$ echo "MAC evbyminsd58df" | cut -d" " -f1
MAC

$ read a _ <<< "MAC evbyminsd58df"
$ echo "$a"
MAC

$ echo "MAC evbyminsd58df" | { read a _; echo "$a"; }
MAC

so_51436874: a=($(rsense -version 2>&1))
echo ${a[2]}        # arrays count from zero, awk counts from 1

echo ${a[-1]}         # assumes a recent version of bash
